description: This changes projections to explicitly use a path length.  I've implemented it for Cartesian and Spherical coordinates, along with a handful of other fixes for Spherical (including a pernicious little bug).
title: Explicitly use path length for projections

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw:
On second thought, I like the symmetry with the spherical case, +1 to this.

What about naming these fields `path_element_[x,y,z]`?  Similarly for the spherical fields below.  I think having a more explicit field name is in keeping with the broader field naming system in yt.
content.html:
On second thought, I like the symmetry with the spherical case, +1 to this.

What about naming these fields path_element_[x,y,z]? Similarly for the spherical fields below. I think having a more explicit field name is in keeping with the broader field naming system in yt.

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw: Because in the projection code it's using path, so that non-Cartesian things work.

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw: Because this is to help guard against ill-formed coordinate systemed parameter files.

content.raw:
The reason I was curious is that as far as I can see, this isn't called anywhere, so how is it guarding against anything?

Couldn't we rephrase this check in a way that either tests the code somehow or validates datasets?

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw:
Hard to say, except:

1. For files with `ds.no_cgs_equiv_length == False` then it should be the same as Cartesian. 
2. Otherwise, probably nothing, especially for spectral cubes (the projection in that case should really only always be "sum").
content.html:
Hard to say, except:

  1. For files with ds.no_cgs_equiv_length == False then it should be the same as Cartesian.
  2. Otherwise, probably nothing, especially for spectral cubes (the projection in that case should really only always be "sum").

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw: Hi John, so should the path element be 1.0 along that axis, or should it be "dpath"?
content.html: Hi John, so should the path element be 1.0 along that axis, or should it be "dpath"?

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw:
Sorry--what is "dpath"? Is that just the infinitesimal line element? 

I think that it should be 1.0, unless `ds.no_cgs_equiv_length == False`.
content.html:
Sorry--what is "dpath"? Is that just the infinitesimal line element?

I think that it should be 1.0, unless ds.no_cgs_equiv_length == False.

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw: Hi @jzuhone , I'm going through this and I think I have it mostly.  Still not sure why the tests fail.  Can you review the change I made, where I mostly copy/pasted the `setup_fields` from Cartesian, but made `path_element` 1.0 everywhere?  This will make all projections have path element 1.0 when projecting, which should have the same effect.
content.html: Hi John ZuHone , I'm going through this and I think I have it mostly. Still not sure why the tests fail. Can you review the change I made, where I mostly copy/pasted the setup_fields from Cartesian, but made path_element 1.0 everywhere? This will make all projections have path element 1.0 when projecting, which should have the same effect.

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw:
@MatthewTurk, I suspect that this is not all that needs to be done here. 

It would appear that the result of multiplying by a dimensionless `dl` should give you the same units when making a projection. But if you look above in `self.get_data`, lines 345-367:

```python
            # add length units to "projected units" if non-weighted 
            # integral projection
            if self.weight_field is None and not self._sum_only and \
               self.method == 'integrate':
                # See _handle_chunk where we mandate cm
                if units == '':
                    input_units = "cm"
                else:
                    input_units = "(%s) * cm" % units
            else:
                input_units = units
            # Don't forget [non_nan] somewhere here.
            self[field] = YTArray(field_data[fi].ravel(),
                                  input_units=input_units,
                                  registry=self.ds.unit_registry)
            # convert units if non-weighted integral projection
            if self.weight_field is None and not self._sum_only and \
               self.method == 'integrate':
                u_obj = Unit(units, registry=self.ds.unit_registry)
                if ((u_obj.is_code_unit or self.ds.no_cgs_equiv_length) and
                    not u_obj.is_dimensionless) and input_units != units:
                    final_unit = "(%s) * code_length" % units
                    self[field].convert_to_units(final_unit)
```
 
then we still end up converting the units to something times a length, regardless of what happens here in `_handle_chunk`:

Unless I am misunderstanding the point of this, which I may be.
content.html:
Matthew Turk, I suspect that this is not all that needs to be done here.

It would appear that the result of multiplying by a dimensionless dl should give you the same units when making a projection. But if you look above in self.get_data, lines 345-367:

            # add length units to "projected units" if non-weighted 
            # integral projection
            if self.weight_field is None and not self._sum_only and \
               self.method == 'integrate':
                # See _handle_chunk where we mandate cm
                if units == '':
                    input_units = "cm"
                else:
                    input_units = "(%s) * cm" % units
            else:
                input_units = units
            # Don't forget [non_nan] somewhere here.
            self[field] = YTArray(field_data[fi].ravel(),
                                  input_units=input_units,
                                  registry=self.ds.unit_registry)
            # convert units if non-weighted integral projection
            if self.weight_field is None and not self._sum_only and \
               self.method == 'integrate':
                u_obj = Unit(units, registry=self.ds.unit_registry)
                if ((u_obj.is_code_unit or self.ds.no_cgs_equiv_length) and
                    not u_obj.is_dimensionless) and input_units != units:
                    final_unit = "(%s) * code_length" % units
                    self[field].convert_to_units(final_unit)

then we still end up converting the units to something times a length, regardless of what happens here in _handle_chunk:

Unless I am misunderstanding the point of this, which I may be.

content.html: You're not misunderstanding it. Thanks for the pointer... now to figure out what the Right Thing To Do is.

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw:
@MatthewTurk the test failures are expected here--the answers have changed because the units have changed. We can just update the answers for the fits projection tests. 

Can we add a deprecation warning for `method = "sum"`? I really don't see a reason for it except for FITS spectral cubes, and this is a better way of handling it.
content.html:
Matthew Turk the test failures are expected here--the answers have changed because the units have changed. We can just update the answers for the fits projection tests.

Can we add a deprecation warning for method = "sum"? I really don't see a reason for it except for FITS spectral cubes, and this is a better way of handling it.

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw:
@jzuhone , @ngoldbaum suggested we not deprecate "sum".  I'm also not entirely sure I want to deprecate it.  Would you be okay with us simply updating the FITS answers?

And, from my reading, the only thing that changed in the FITS answers is the units -- is that correct?  The values should remain identical?
content.html:
John ZuHone , Nathan Goldbaum suggested we not deprecate "sum". I'm also not entirely sure I want to deprecate it. Would you be okay with us simply updating the FITS answers?

And, from my reading, the only thing that changed in the FITS answers is the units -- is that correct? The values should remain identical?

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw:
I don't feel strongly about it, but to be honest after this PR is pulled in I fail to see how it will be useful, since now FITS cubes will be projected in this manner by default, even when `method == "integrate"`. Any future data formats with similar issues will probably have the behavior for path length set in a similar way. In my view, what we're doing here is implementing the same behavior in a better and more consistent way, so it seems like it completely replaces what we were trying to accomplish with `method == "sum"`.

Otherwise, yes, all that changed were the units in the answer tests.
content.html:
I don't feel strongly about it, but to be honest after this PR is pulled in I fail to see how it will be useful, since now FITS cubes will be projected in this manner by default, even when method == "integrate". Any future data formats with similar issues will probably have the behavior for path length set in a similar way. In my view, what we're doing here is implementing the same behavior in a better and more consistent way, so it seems like it completely replaces what we were trying to accomplish with method == "sum".

Otherwise, yes, all that changed were the units in the answer tests.

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw: What if for some reason I want to calculate a sum rather than a line integral? I don't think we should remove that capability, that's all.
content.html: What if for some reason I want to calculate a sum rather than a line integral? I don't think we should remove that capability, that's all.

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw: I'm also a bit confused by the units of the FITS projections, aren't we projecting down the velocity axis?  I thought the ambiguity between spectral aces and spatial aces was the main reason we were using sums instead of line integrals for FITS data.  What changed here that made that concern go away?
content.html: I'm also a bit confused by the units of the FITS projections, aren't we projecting down the velocity axis? I thought the ambiguity between spectral aces and spatial aces was the main reason we were using sums instead of line integrals for FITS data. What changed here that made that concern go away?

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw: Okay -- I've checked, and projecting "sum" does the right thing, and does not multiply by path length or by units.  So I think it *is* working, and I think we should be good to go if FITS answers get updated.  @xarthisius ?
content.html: Okay -- I've checked, and projecting "sum" does the right thing, and does not multiply by path length or by units. So I think it is working, and I think we should be good to go if FITS answers get updated. Kacper Kowalik ?

pullrequest.title: Explicitly use path length for projections

content.raw:
@jzuhone ignore these comments.  I was misreading the error from the failing test - the old answers where we multiply by `code-length` is just straight up incorrect.  What Matt's doing here, mulitplying by a unitless path element, is clearly the correct answer.

We just need to regenerate the answers and we should be good to go.
content.html:
John ZuHone ignore these comments. I was misreading the error from the failing test - the old answers where we multiply by code-length is just straight up incorrect. What Matt's doing here, mulitplying by a unitless path element, is clearly the correct answer.

We just need to regenerate the answers and we should be good to go.
